pullRequest.body:
Define transtition map between ring or module quotient by powers of ideal, both for developing API for IsAdicComplete

Co-authored-by: @jjdishere emailboxofjjd@163.com

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> I've nothing against this, but I am worried that people start proving stuff about your map instead of the more general `factor`. Can you explain a little why you think this is really needed? Instead of, for example, working with an `abbrev` or something.

For me I doesn't need it that urgently, the only cost of using the module version is a bit longer and more ugly proof. The real reason may need @jjdishere to answer.
Also there is an problem remaining: the version of `mapQPow` he proposed is only the special case for `AdicCompletion.transitionMap` for adjcent integer and the current version is the exact same, we may need some more discussion.

The result of the discussion is we decide to separate `AdicCompletion.transitionMap` out of `AdicCompletion.Basic` to this file, and leave the `AdicCompletion.transitionMap` and the ones for adjcent onns as abbreviations. What do you think?

I've nothing against this, but I am worried that people start proving stuff about your map instead of the more general `factor`. Can you explain a little why you think this is really needed? Instead of, for example, working with an `abbrev` or something.
Can you move the comments about location of the file out of the "main" docstring? They're good comment, having them as `--comment` is OK I think, no need to have them in the webpage.
Are we missing a lemma here (instead of the `rfl`?

The `rfl` can be replaced by the following:
```lean
have : out x = (Ideal.Quotient.mk (I ^ m) x.out) := rfl
 simp only [this, factorPow_mk]
```
however I doesn't clearly know what is the missing thing for the first line, and I don't know how to operate the thing with bracket on LHS, although I met several times.
Well, maybe the question is: do you really need this lemma? Using `out` seems weird.
Sorry that this lemma isn't proposed by me, I think this need @jjdishere to answer.
I mean, `x.out` is any lifting obtained by choice. it seems bad to have a lemma specific to this lifting. No objection to a lemma relative to *any* lifting (that is essentially the one before).

For me, I understand this lemma as the lemma to show `x.out` *is* a lifting. Without this lemma, we have to directly use the theorem [Quotient.out_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Quot.html#Quotient.out_eq). And it has a form that is simplifying from LHS to RHS, so I add a `@[simp]` tag here. (Note that [Quotient.out_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Quot.html#Quotient.out_eq) also has a `@[simp]` tag.) Do you think this lemma is ok, but we should not tag it with `@[simp]`?

About the usage of this lemma: In the definition of `IsPrecomplete`, if one has a compatible sequence `x n` in some ring `R`, then it has a limit `x` in `R`. I would like to build an API for "If one has a compatible sequence in `R/I^n`, then it has a limit `x` in `R`". The shortest way to prove this is to take arbitrary lifts `(x n).out` and show they form a compatible sequence in `R`. To show that these lifts map back to `x n`, one needs this lemma.

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory/Ideal/Quotient): define transtition map between ring or module quotient by powers of ideal

I've nothing against this, but I am worried that people start proving stuff about your map instead of the more general `factor`. Can you explain a little why you think this is really needed? Instead of, for example, working with an `abbrev` or something.

> I've nothing against this, but I am worried that people start proving stuff about your map instead of the more general `factor`. Can you explain a little why you think this is really needed? Instead of, for example, working with an `abbrev` or something.

For me I doesn't need it that urgently, the only cost of using the module version is a bit longer and more ugly proof. The real reason may need @jjdishere to answer.
Also there is an problem remaining: the version of `mapQPow` he proposed is only the special case for `AdicCompletion.transitionMap` for adjcent integer and the current version is the exact same, we may need some more discussion.

The result of the discussion is we decide to separate `AdicCompletion.transitionMap` out of `AdicCompletion.Basic` to this file, and leave the `AdicCompletion.transitionMap` and the ones for adjcent onns as abbreviations. What do you think?
